title: Book Review: Infinite Jest (alternate title: “Look At Me! I Read Infinite Jest!”)
summary:
Key ideas:
- Infinite Jest is a book with a fractally complex narrative about the dangers of self-reference
- The book centers around wireheading and the difference between pleasure and purpose
- These themes are explored through characters like drug addicts and hypercompetitive children
- The book also explores the importance of interpersonal communication
- Infinite Jest blurs the boundaries between text and reality.
- The book seeks to reach the true core beneath postmodernist society and bring it back to reality.
- The ending of the book is mysterious and difficult to explain.

Key learnings:
- Seeking pleasure alone is not enough, and life needs to have purpose
- Competition can be useless and even damaging
- Connecting to something outside oneself is important
- Genuine interpersonal communication is key
- The book highlights people's obsession with meaningless entertainment that doesn't involve interpersonal communication.
- The book seems like meaningless entertainment but is actually complicated and leads to true interpersonal communication with the author.
- The author may be represented by James Incandenza in the book.

Key questions:
- What is the significance of the O.N.A.N. society in the book?
- How are addiction and wireheading related in the book?
- What is the importance of Hal Incandenza's character?
- Can genuine interpersonal communication help combat the dangers of wireheading?
- What is the significance of blurring the boundaries between text and reality in Infinite Jest?
- Why is the ending of the book so mysterious?
- What is the true core beneath postmodernist society that the author seeks to reach and bring back to reality?
